bibl.title: Despatch from Owen L. W. Smith to David J. Hill, February 7, 1901
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

keywords.term: Harper, Cape Palmas, Maryland County, Liberia

correspAction.roleName: U.S. Minister Resident and Consul General

div1.p: No. 61. Consular. Legation of the United States Monrovia Liberia Feb'y 7, 1901
Hon. David J. Hill Assistant Secretary of State Washington.

p.add: See letters to Mr of Dec 31 1900 or June 1900

div1.p: Subject. Receipt of Dispatch No. 29, December 31, 1900, transmitting papers in relation to the Estate of A. M. Miller deceased.
No. 61. Consular Legation of the United States. Monrovia Liberia; February 7, 1901.
Hon. David J. Hill, Assistant Secretary of State, Washington.

Sir: I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt February 6, 1901, of your No. 29. Consular of Dec. 31, 1900, by Alvey A. Addee Esq. Second Assistant Secretary of State, transmitting papers &c, from Hon. C. E. Littlefield, in relation to the estate of the late A. M. Miller, deceased late of Harper Cape Palmas, Maryland County Liberia.
In reply, the matter has my immediate attention. I have this morning called upon His Excelency the President the

the former Secretary of State, whose son, W. V. Gibson is now Acting Secretary of State, under the immediate supervision of the father; now President, relative to the matter. His Excellency promises to have the matter, including the demand upon Senator F. O. Thorn, for the immediate return of the certificates of Maryland County currency, for the sum of Four Hundred, Fifty-six 59/100 Dollars, due the estate of, the deceased; to be redeemed by the Liberian Government, to be looked after, at once, through the proper channel.
I have the honor to be your obedient servant; Owen L. W. Smith, Consul General.
